analyzeResult.content:
The Arizona Republic/THE PHOENIX GAZETTE . Wed, May 16, 1990
Randy Reld / Staff photographer ulle Carpenter won a contest with or anti-smoking rap song.
Girl's song raps smoking, wins contest
By Bryan Snyder Special to Community
CHANDLER - Sixth-grader Julie Car- penter has a varied personality. One minute she's disc jockey Jazzy Julie, the next minute she's sportscaster J.J. Car- panter.
As radio rapper and disc jockey queen at KdSTR 590AM, the nation's only radio station operated by children, Julie has- become quite a radio personality at Shumway Elementary School in Chan- dler.
"She's got quite a flair for the theatri- cal," said her mother, Joy.
Indeed, she does. The 11-year-old also has a social conscience, and she combined the two qualities to record an anti-smok- ing rap song that took the grand prize in a public service announcement content sponsored by the non-profit organization, Coalition for Smoke-Free Air.
Julie won & $50 savings bond.
. "I didn't think I'd win," she said. "1 . maan, I've never won anything before. except for a coloring contest."
Julie first heard of the contest from ber music teacher, Linda Minton. At first, she wrote a simple report on the dangers of smoking.
"But everybody else was doing that," she explained. "I wanted to do something unique."
So she used the example of her favorite rap performers, Rob Base and Tone Loc, for inspiration. She also enlisted the aid of her father, Ron, whowe own father was a smoker who died of emphysema
"I really never knew my grandfather," said Julie, who dedicated her anti-smok- ing rap song to her grandfather. "I wasn't very old when he died."
The numerous No Smoking rigne scat- tered throughout the Carpenter household also had a direct influence on the See SMOKING, Page 3
Now sit down children and lend me your ear.
About a bed addiction that you should fear.
It smells and stinks and waters your eyes.
It lingers in your clothes and gives you hiver.
It stains your windows and darkens your teeth.
It steale your life like a meaking thief. Each nail in your coffin, it shortens your life,
It cuts your time like a sharpened knife. They shouldn't make it, sell it, or give it away.
Cigarette smoking should be blown AWAY.
It ain't so cool, it's really pretty sick, Playing Russian roulette with a cancer stick.
TI1731-0945
SMOKING
: theatrical youngster.
.""Oh yeah, they're everywhere." "she said. "But I'm glad they are, and I'm glad my parents don't Â· smoke. I have a lot of friends : whose parents smoke, and I feel : sorry for them. They're always : trying to get them to stop."
: . Carpenter holds down a number - of duties at the school's radio *station. In addition to being a disc jockey and sportscaster, she also is programmer. engineer, spot re- porter and faculty feature reporter at KdSTR.
"She's a bright student and very .expressive - a born actress." " Minton said."She's also very cre- "I can see her doing some fascinating things when she gets *ative ood spontan.www Rise a aHer, either in broaderstire or in :
her alley." Carpenter isn't shy being around famous people. As a sports- caster, she's already interviewed two members of the Phoenix Suns basketball team, Dan Majerle and Mark West.
"You can't be embarrassed at all being on the air," she explained. "You have to have guts, especially knowing you can mess up 50 easily:"
Julie, who has visions of being an actress, already has convinced her music teacher of her many talents.
From Page 1
